Vincia: activity diagrams annotations grammar
Last Published: 02 June 2013  

IF Statements

IF-statement bifurcations in the flow should be shown in the diagram either when there are annotated actions inside or when we have 'highlighted/underlined' the if-statement with the //$ notation. We can add user-defined conditions before or after the if- elseif- else- statements. We can also quote the calls to functions/methods in the conditions. Finally, there are zooming options.

annotation

a) comments after: 

      if(conditionStatement)  //$     
      //$ [condition A]
      {
      //$ action 1
      code
      //$ action 2           
      code
      }
      else if(conditionStatement)  //$
      //$ [condition B]
      {
      //$ action 3
      code
      }
      else                                  
      //$ [condition C]
      {
      code
      }

a) comments before: 

      //$ [condition A]      
      if(conditionStatement) {   //$
      //$ action 1
      code
      //$ action 2           
      code
      }
      //$ [condition B]
      else if(conditionStatement) {  //$
      //$ action 3
      code
      }
      //$ [condition C]
      else{
      code
      }

//$: forces displaying in the diagram the calls to functions/methods inside the conditionStatement
//$ [condition A]: specifies the condition; the square brackets [ ] are required syntax

representation in the diagram

  • When there is (at least) an action in any of the conditional paths, the whole IF-diagram will be drawn at the corresponding zoom level, including the ‘else’ path (whether this one is written in the code or not).
  • The comments specifying the conditions are optional. They will also drive the drawing of the IF-diagram, in a secondary basis.
  • The conditions that are not specified will be taken from the code. In particular, the default condition for the ‘else’ conditional path is [else].

calls to functions/methods in the conditionStatements
When the condition(s) involve a call(s) to a method/function, these will be shown as actionable hyperlinks, provided that there exists the relevant diagram(s):
  • conditionStatement read directly from the code: always shown. Example:
  • user-defined condition: shown only if the //$ option is present. Example:

examples

Example with nested IF-Statements 

      void activity_function(int a){
      
      int c=2;
      //$ [condition A]
      if(a>0) {
      //$ action 1
      std::cout<<"do 1"<< endl;
        //$ [condition A.1]
        if (a>c)            
        {
        //$ action 4
        std::cout<<"do 4"<< endl;
        }
      }
      //$ [condition B]
      else if(a==-1) {
      //$ action 3
      std::cout<<"do 3"<< endl;
      }
      //$ [condition C]
      else {
      std::cout<<"do nothing"<< endl;
      }
      
      return;
      }
